documents.t: Qpon is a self-hosted coupon management system designed for businesses to create, manage and track coupons easily. The API-first design ensures seamless integration with your existing systems, making it easy to automate workflows and manage coupon data in real time.
Introduction to QPON API authorization methods
Qpon can be deployed using Docker. It requires a PostgreSQL database to run.

Qpon is a self-hosted coupon management system designed for businesses to create, manage and track coupons easily. The API-first design ensures seamless integration with your existing systems, making it easy to automate workflows and manage coupon data in real time.

Features: Self-Hosted Deploy Qpon on your own servers for full control over your data and security. RESTful API Integrate Qpon with your existing systems using its REST API, allowing automated coupon management, real-time tracking, and reporting. Multi-tenant Manage multiple brands, stores, or campaigns from a single platform with dedicated API endpoints for each. Custom Coupon Rules Define custom rules for coupon creation, including value-based discounts, usage limits, or specific redemption conditions via API. Real-Time Tracking Monitor coupon usage, redemption rates, and campaign performance in real-time. Role-Based Access Control Define user roles and permissions for API access, ensuring secure and controlled access to coupon data.
The Qpon API supports two authorization methods for authenticating your requests. Choose the method that best fits your use case.

This method uses JWT tokens obtained through the login endpoint. Include the token in the Authorization header. Usage: Authorization: Bearer <your-jwt-token> Example: GET /api/coupons Authorization: Bearer eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJzdWIiOiI0MTQxMjgwZS0yODE0LTQxZGEtOTg1NS1iZTk3MWY4ZDk3NGUiLCJpYXQiOjE3NTk5OTM4NDAsImV4cCI6MTc2MDA4MDI0MH0.0aNHQLZVz6i_uY9ruh1Qm6dDgzxX_zUqHFp0HupvT64 How to get a token: Call the /api/users/login endpoint with your email and password Extract the access_token from the response Use this token in subsequent API calls

This method uses API keys for programmatic access. Include both the API key and secret in the request headers. Usage: x-api-key: <your-api-key> x-api-secret: <your-api-secret> Example: GET /api/coupons x-api-key: 1234567890abcdef x-api-secret: abcdef1234567890 How to get API keys: Call the /api/api-keys endpoint to create an API key Store the returned api_key and api_secret securely Use these credentials in your API requests
Bearer Token: Best for user-facing applications where users log in with their credentials API Key: Best for server-to-server communication, integrations, and automated systems

Keep your tokens and API keys secure and never expose them in client-side code API keys should be rotated regularly for security Bearer tokens have expiration times and need to be refreshed Use HTTPS for all API requests to protect credentials in transit

Both authorization methods return 401 Unauthorized if: The token is invalid or expired The API key/secret combination is incorrect Required headers are missing { "code": 401, "message": "Unauthorized" }
Responses 201 404 201 Successfully created api keys 404 Organization not found
Responses 201 401 409 201 Customer created 401 Unauthorized 409 Customer already exists
Responses 201 400 409 201 Organization created 400 Invalid body 409 Organization already exists
Responses 201 409 201 Successfully created super admin 409 Super Admin already exists
Responses 201 400 409 201 User created successfully 400 Bad request 409 User already exists
Responses 200 404 200 Successfully deactivated coupon 404 Coupon not found
Responses 200 404 200 Organization deleted 404 Organization not found
Responses 200 404 200 Successfully deleted user 404 User not found
Responses 200 404 200 Successfully fetched api key 404 Api key not found
Responses 200 404 200 Fetched coupon 404 Coupon not found
Responses 200 401 404 200 Coupon code fetched 401 Unauthorized 404 Coupon code not found
GET /api/organizations/:organization_id/coupon-codes Fetch coupon code by code
Responses 200 404 200 Fetched Sheet json 404 Not Found
Responses 200 200 Fetched summary of all coupons in an organization
Responses 200 404 200 Organization fetched 404 Organization not found
Responses 200 404 200 Successfully fetched 404 Organization not found
GET /api/organizations/:organization_id/coupons/:coupon_id/campaigns/:campaign_id/coupon-codes/:coupon_code_id/redemptions Fetch redemptions for coupon code
Responses 200 404 200 Fetched user 404 User not found
Responses 200 404 200 Successfully fetched 404 Users not found
GET /api/organizations/:organization_id/users Fetch users of an organization
Responses 200 404 200 Fetch users 404 Users not found

Qpon can be deployed using Docker. It requires a PostgreSQL database to run. The latest image is available on Docker Hub at labsatquicko/qpon:latest Download the compose file curl -LO https://github.com/org-quicko/qpon/raw/main/docker-compose.yml Set the environment variables curl -LO https://github.com/org-quicko/qpon/raw/main/.env.example # create a .env file and set the environment variables cp .env.example .env Start the services docker compose up -d Visit http://localhost:3000/setup to set up the super admin user.

Variable Description Example DB_USERNAME Database username qpon_user DB_PASSWORD Database password strongpassword DB_NAME Database name qpon_db DB_HOST Database host db (use 'db' for Docker) JWT_SECRET JWT signing secret any-random-string SALT_ROUNDS Bcrypt salt rounds for passwords 10 These variables can be set in a .env file, in your shell, or directly in docker-compose.yml.
Responses 201 400 404 409 200 Successfully redeemed 400 Customer not eligible 404 Coupon code not found 409 Customer has already redeemed coupon code
Responses 200 404 200 Successfully updated coupon 404 Coupon not found
Responses 200 404 200 Organization updated 404 Organization not found
PATCH /api/organizations/:organization_id/users/:user_id/role Update user role in organization
